stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and tunes the “Wumpa” gate NPC/cutscene, begins designing a bombable wall for the Bowser-fight approach, and then pivots into overworld progression work: fixing Bowser 2 warp/area setup, reflecting on overworld scale and readability, and prototyping anti-skip gating with a mudslide. He also shares a concrete plan to open-source the RTYI engine by removing all remaining Nintendo code, and briefly showcases the near-finished “Mars Expansion” project while arguing it should migrate to the RTYI engine/physics.
stream_context.significance_reason: He finishes a major overworld segment (“part VII”), sets up a new progression gate (Wumpa + bombable wall), and lays out a specific open-source release plan for the RTYI engine (including a community audit to reach “0% Nintendo code”).

findings.summary: Kaze considers the Wumpa gate NPC effectively “programmed” after fixing teleport offsets, adding a blocking hitbox, and tuning the approach movement so the star-gated cutscene consistently lines up regardless of the player’s talk angle.

He identifies a cinematic/design constraint: because the NPC’s facing/approach depends on Mario’s relative angle at interaction, the original cutscene logic produced inconsistent staging; he replaces it with a “good enough” fixed-angle approach (~30 degrees) to stabilize presentation.

He reiterates a boundary for compatibility: he will not “fix emulators,” and if certain emulators run the hack extremely slowly it’s treated as an emulator/plugin cost rather than his problem; later he corrects himself on a crash, attributing it to his own null-pointer bug rather than emulation.

He showcases “Mars Expansion” as very close to content-complete: all levels are in-game and all 10 stars per level are finished; current work is importing/enabling ‘little enemies’ and cleaning up debug issues.

He argues strongly that future releases (including Mars Expansion) should move to the RTYI engine/physics because he personally “cannot deal with Mario 64’s physics anymore,” framing RTYI feel as a quality bar for what he’s willing to ship and play.
findings.quote: Personally, I cannot deal with Mario 64's physics anymore. So if someone released a ROM hack that's not based on RTYI, I just wouldn't play it.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines an explicit open-source strategy for the RTYI engine: finish the engine, reach ‘0% Nintendo code,’ then strip RTYI-specific game content and release a minimal public engine (Mario in a flat field), asking the community to help identify remaining Nintendo code and propose improvements.
findings.quote: I'm going to finish the RTYI Engine, hopefully get to 0% Nintendo Code... and release just the engine with Mario in a flat field to the public.

findings.summary: He notes Fast64/Blender pipeline instability: sometimes he must disable Fast64, restart Blender, then re-enable to recover from a broken state; recompiles are quick unless doing a clean build.

From looking at other homebrew tools (e.g., Tiny3D), he calls out missing N64 audio-threading as a serious flaw: without an audio thread, minor frame lag makes audio “really annoying,” implying RTYI prioritizes decoupling audio from frame performance.

For the Bowser-fight approach he plans a bombable wall that should be visually distinct but not overthought yet (‘temporary art’). He intends the wall’s broken state to persist via save flags so it stays open permanently once destroyed.
He hits a hard engine constraint: the current setup allows 255 model IDs (“by default in the Mario 64 engine”), and he runs out, forcing a future task to expand or reorganize model ID usage.
findings.quote: You can have 255 different models by default in the Mario 64 engine. I have not expanded on that.

findings.summary: He realizes and states he has finished “part VII” of the overworld and that remaining overworld segments (parts XIV–XV in the sky) should be comparatively easy to program, shifting focus to other remaining parts (IX/XIII).

He diagnoses the Bowser 2 access problem as a warp/area setup issue: one area contains interiors; another has missing warps, creating ‘missing warp’ errors and crashes. He edits warp destinations/exits to restore traversal.

He reinforces the core overworld pillar: the overworld will transform as the player progresses, culminating in a final boss fight that takes place in (and corrupts) the overworld itself; he worries recent courses haven’t driven enough visible overworld changes and considers adding course-linked NPCs/creatures appearing in the hub.

He flags an exploration/readability issue: a critical forward path is visually unclear (players may not realize progress later enables climbing). He rejects obvious signage as too ‘lazy’ and instead prototypes terrain-based gating and curiosity cues.

To prevent sequence breaks, he prototypes a mudslide as a progression gate after testing and discovering the slope was skippable with precise movement; he intends to adjust walls and terrain so the block feels natural while still preventing skips.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions Biobak is still reworking some levels (courses 13–15 noted as not heavily tested yet), implying ongoing iteration and polish are in progress beyond this stream’s overworld tasks.

Kaze jokes that a random Minecraft-like texture used for the crack/bomb-wall concept art was something ‘Biobak slid’ into the project files, indicating shared asset libraries and informal iteration during prototyping.

badub.summary: Kaze confirms the team is not just him and Biobak: Badub continues contributing music, with Kaze auditioning tracks on stream while developing.

zeina.summary: In a discussion about wrist pain and ergonomics, Kaze mentions Zeina uses a wrist cushion that seems helpful, hinting at day-to-day health/workflow adaptations in their shared environment.

findings.summary: Kaze addresses UltraFP64 about a prior video discussing the Analogue 3D, saying he meant to praise UltraFP64’s work while criticizing Analogue’s advertising claims; later he mentions an ‘engineer’ message that Analogue 3D analog input was ‘fixed,’ but he can’t show it.
Kaze mentions Namu as someone who could potentially clarify a crash/issue (‘tell us something proper’), implying a technical collaborator he can consult for debugging or engine-level knowledge.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Personally, I cannot deal with Mario 64's physics anymore. So if someone released a ROM hack that's not based on RTYI, I just wouldn't play it.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why other projects (like Mars Expansion) should migrate onto the RTYI engine/physics, setting a personal quality bar that influences technical direction.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I'm going to finish the RTYI Engine, hopefully get to 0% Nintendo Code... and release just the engine with Mario in a flat field to the public.
memorable_quotes.context: Concrete plan for open-sourcing the engine and inviting community review to remove remaining Nintendo code.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Playtesting is by far the most important part of the game development process.
memorable_quotes.context: After iterating on overworld gating and anti-skip measures, he generalizes a core development philosophy about testing-driven design.

key_stories.title: Open-sourcing RTYI via a ‘0% Nintendo code’ audit
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines a step-by-step release plan for the RTYI engine: finish it, remove Nintendo code, then publish a minimal engine build for community improvements and code-auditing. He frames it as necessary for a proper open-source foundation that others can build new games on.
key_stories.challenge: How to legally and practically open-source an engine derived from/adjacent to SM64-era code while ensuring it contains no Nintendo-owned code.
key_stories.process: Finish RTYI engine → reach an internal target of ‘0% Nintendo code’ → strip RTYI-specific content → release a minimal demo (Mario in a flat field) → ask the public to identify remaining Nintendo code and propose improvements.
key_stories.outcome: Plan is declared but not yet executed; it becomes an explicit roadmap item and community collaboration point.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm going to ask people to find improvements on the engine, to point out any remaining Nintendo Code so we can remove that.

key_stories.title: Overworld gating iteration: from unclear path to mudslide anti-skip
key_stories.summary: While shaping the Yoshi-village overworld segment, Kaze notices players may not realize a future climbable route exists. He tests a terrain-based solution (a slope), discovers it can be skipped with precise movement, and pivots to a mudslide gate to preserve intended progression while keeping the world readable and intriguing.
key_stories.challenge: Make progression routes discoverable without immersion-breaking signage, while preventing sequence breaks and movement exploits.
key_stories.process: Identify readability problem → reject signs/‘yellow paint’ → prototype slope-based hint → test for skips → confirm skippable → implement mudslide to enforce progression → re-evaluate wall heights/geometry to reduce unnecessary collision mass.
key_stories.outcome: Mudslide gate becomes the preferred solution; remaining task is ensuring it still ‘feels’ fair and readable.

key_stories.title: Bowser 2 crash traced to warp/area configuration
key_stories.summary: Trying to enter the Bowser 2 level from the overworld, Kaze hits missing-warp behavior and instability. He investigates the level’s area layout, finds a missing warp and confusing warp entries, and adjusts warp destinations/exits to restore correct traversal.
key_stories.challenge: A critical hub-to-boss path is blocked by missing warp data and area configuration issues, risking late-game progression flow.
key_stories.process: Attempt entry → observe missing warp → inspect area setup (interiors in one area, missing warp in another) → review warp list → edit destinations/exits → retest access.
key_stories.outcome: Warp setup is partially corrected in-stream; remaining polish and retesting implied.

open_questions.topic: Defining and achieving ‘0% Nintendo code’ for an open-source RTYI engine
open_questions.context: Kaze states a goal to remove all Nintendo code before releasing the engine publicly and asks the community to help find remaining Nintendo code once a minimal engine build is released.
questions: What is the concrete definition of ‘Nintendo code’ for RTYI (function-level lineage, data tables, macros, asset formats, tool scripts, etc.)?
What internal process or tooling (diffing, provenance tracking, clean-room rewrites) is used to validate the ‘0%’ claim before public release?
What parts are expected to remain legally risky even after rewrites (e.g., animation data formats, behavior scripts, original constants)?
What does the ‘flat field with Mario’ release contain exactly (physics, camera, collision, audio, input, rendering), and what is intentionally excluded?
How will community reports of suspected Nintendo code be triaged and resolved without turning into endless scope creep?

open_questions.topic: Migrating Mars Expansion onto RTYI engine/physics
open_questions.context: Kaze says Mars Expansion is close to done content-wise but ‘needs’ the RTYI engine or it will be a disappointing release, because he no longer likes SM64 physics.
questions: What specifically about RTYI physics is non-negotiable for Mars Expansion (movement feel, camera, collision response, exploit handling, etc.)?
What is the estimated engineering effort to port Mars Expansion to RTYI (level scripts, enemies, interactions, save system), and what is the biggest blocker?
Would the port delay release, or would you ship a ‘legacy-physics’ version first and upgrade later?
Does RTYI introduce new constraints that could break existing Mars Expansion level design?

open_questions.topic: Engine constraints: the 255 model ID limit
open_questions.context: Kaze runs out of model IDs and notes the current engine remains at the default 255-model limit from the SM64 baseline.
questions: What content pushed RTYI over the 255 model-ID limit (overworld set dressing, enemies, UI models, cutscene props)?
What is the planned fix: expanding the ID space, streaming models per-area, dynamic allocation, or consolidating shared geometry?
How risky is changing this late (save compatibility, tooling, Fast64 export assumptions, level scripts)?
Are there other similar ‘hidden SM64 limits’ still unaddressed that could surface during final content integration?

open_questions.topic: Overworld transformation system and course-to-hub feedback loop
open_questions.context: Kaze emphasizes that the overworld will change as you progress and the final boss fight will take place in a corrupted overworld. He worries recent courses don’t visibly affect the hub enough and considers adding course-linked characters/creatures to the overworld.
questions: What is the technical system for overworld transformations (flags, per-star changes, scene graph swaps, streaming segments)?
Which courses currently drive overworld changes, and which ones feel ‘disconnected’ right now?
What is the design rule for hub changes (cosmetic vs. traversal-changing vs. narrative signaling)?
How will you avoid the overworld becoming too heavy to render/load as it accumulates changes (e.g., watermelon field density concerns)?
What’s the envisioned player emotion for the overworld’s final ‘evil version’—loss of safety, escalation, nostalgia inversion?

open_questions.topic: Movement exploits and RTYI’s relationship to SM64 tech (BLJ, ceilings, upslides)
open_questions.context: During gating tests, Kaze notes RTYI behaves differently than SM64: ceiling BLJ may be gone, upslide/slide behaviors differ, and he finds a skip method he wants to disable and add to a bug list.
questions: What are the explicit goals for exploit support: preserve iconic tech, remove it, or selectively allow it in specific contexts?
Which movement behaviors are intentionally changed from SM64 (and why), versus accidental side effects of new physics?
How do you systematically test for sequence breaks in an overworld built around ‘one continuous space’?
When you ‘disable’ a skip, what tool do you prefer: collision redesign, movement parameter tweaks, or special-case triggers like mudslides?
